Show HN: An Reccurent Event tracker including for software lifecycle
text:
It's a project I'm working for some time, the starting idea was simple: I wanted to get simple notifications when reccurent events happen for example: I go to a site and I want to know when Windows (could be anything else) is launched, see the event in a calandar and get notified only for that every couple of years and nothing else.

Of course as I started to work on it ideas started creeping in so by now it's far more than that.

In the title I mentioned software lifecycle, you can already see this on https://endoflife.date/ but I also wanted to model this in a way that allows you to see them in a calendar besides other events.

If you want to see what is tracked for software you can search for 'software' topic: https://www.beepwhen.com/event-series/topics

Some feedback would be appreciated:

1. Is it is clear from the landing page what the app does? 2. If you think it's useful for you, if not why not , If it's useful, what stops you from using it

I'm happy to answer any questions

Thanks!

Ask HN: Good, developer-focused, AI newsletters
text:
I subscribe to most of Cooperpress’s email newsletters (Javascript Weekly, Node Weekly etc). Sadly they don’t do an AI/ML newsletter. I’m more of a web dev so I don’t know much about the field but would like to learn more about it as to me it seems like it’s the most interesting/exciting field in computing atm. Does anyone have any recommendations for newsletters?

Here is Javascript weekly for the kind of thing I’m after:

https://javascriptweekly.com/issues/606

https://nodeweekly.com/issues/455

https://cooperpress.com/publications/

Ask HN: Low level OS-related or ML jobs?
text:
Hi everyone, I'm currently coding as a hobby, and have an intend to get into Tech jobs. I don’t really like business stuffs in SWE, I like CS-related stuffs. What I currently enjoy most is to make an interpreter, and contribute to Tauri - a Rust framework, but i don’t think I can make a living from doing only OSS.

So, I’m considering getting into OS devs, compilers, or even device drivers, embedded, hardware stuffs (I’m more comfortable in software). But these fields are rare, and risky, especially in my country, I don’t think I can get a remote job in these fields without prior experience. Another path I’m considering is Machine Learning, it’s more popular, but on the surface level, it's mainly applying prebuilt techs into business (from what I heard). Maybe, I can get entries jobs and find a way to switch into deeper (research-related) A.I areas?

Can anyone suggest me what suitable path I should follow? Deep dive into OS stuffs or A.I ?
